content: Suppose we're trying to prove (a < b) ∨ p → q, and we have split it up by cases, and we've already demonstrated that a < b → q. Now we're working on the p → q case. Can I somehow bring in the additional hypothesis a ≥ b to help me out in that case? (Rationale: if it weren't true then we would be in the a < b case and we would already be done.) I am not having any luck finding anything about this kind of reasoning in the manual. In case it matters, a and b are Nat.
do you mean ((a < b) ∨ p) → q or (a < b) ∨ (p → q)?
the way to do this would usually be by the law of excluded middle. one way to do this in lean is by using an if h : a < b then ... else ... pattern
yes, I meant ((a < b) ∨ p) → q. I'll try if h: a < b then ... else ....
Zack Weinberg has marked this topic as resolved.
for future readers, split_ifs and rcases lt_trichotomy a b with lt | eq | gt are also useful for this kind of problem.
Even better is often rcases lt_trichotomy a b with lt | rfl | gt where rfl does the substitution
